77 In the foregoing examination, I have thought it right not only to
make known the <u>results</u> of my researches, but so to develop my <u>plan
of investigation</u> that the value of those results may be duly
estimated. In the Memoirs which I trust to be encouraged to
forward from time to time, regarding the other typical forms of
Foraminifera, of which I have made a special study, it is not my
intention to do more than state the results; <s>and I shall desire</s> hoping 
that they may be understood to have been attained by a
method of enquiry as closely resembling that which I have
here followed through its details, as the circumstances of each
case may have admitted. I would have it come in mind
throughout, that, as has been admirably remarked by one of
the most accomplished Botanists of our time, "the Naturalist who
has the true interest of Science at heart, not only feels that the
thrusting of an uncalled-for synonym into the nomenclature of
Science is an exposure of his own ignorance, and deserves censure,
but that a wide range of knowledge and a greater depth of
study are required to prove those dissimilar forms to be identical,
which any superficial observer can separate by words and a
name" (Dr. J.D. Hooker, Op cit, p xiv note)
